commits.commitMessage:
Prototype of MCU <-> MAP communication

This commit makes the following changes:

- Includes 'endian.h' in the Framework Adaptor for the HL78 RTOS build,

- Fixes issue with endian.h implementation affecting Big Endian architectures,

- Calls the underlying implementation for the function,
le_msg_RequestResponse().

- Removes duplicate function implementations for le_msg_GetClientUserId()
and le_msg_GetClientProcessId().

Resolves: LE-12984
Change-Id: I5b652f936b9ac68a0af9f78ab0f63e7121936a0a
commits.subject: Prototype of MCU <-> MAP communication

commits.commitMessage:
[Timers] Fix a race condition in event loop

Issue:
A timer expires, TimerFdHandler() is queued onto the event loop,
and another event handler stops the timer before TimerFdHandler()
is really called which leads to an ASSERT

Fix:
Call TimerFdHandler() when timer expires immediatly

Resolves: LE-11946
Change-Id: Ia366b90dbf1adf3ce54d70648dfbf80e390b8394
commits.subject: [Timers] Fix a race condition in event loop

comments.message:
Technically you should use CONTAINER_OF to get timer_Altair1250ThreadRec_t* which contains threadRecPtr, then release that, as it's the outer timer_Altair1250ThreadRec_t which is allocated.  

However since timer_ThreadRec_t is the first member of the structure, this will have no functional impact.

commits.commitMessage:
Override default logging macros with SFP logging functions

On HL78 use SFP logging functions to override default Legato
log macros.  This approach is chosen instead of the original
approach of implementing a new _le_log_Send() function as
eventually these will be replaced with calls to SFP_LOG_...(),
which need to be invoked in-place.

This uses the same logging module as SWISERVER.

Resolves: LE-11552
Change-Id: I7f76aa5b92b3eb4b8a0c434e196aa4ee2f7e5a0d
commits.subject: Override default logging macros with SFP logging functions

> Looks ok to me, but it's a pity we are adding yet another implementation of fcntl() for RTOS beside frameworkAdaptor/liblegato/fcntl.c.
> Isn't there anything we could do to avoid this ?

Implement LE-9183.  I made the same comment when the le_fd API was implemented: https://gerrit-legato/c/Legato/frameworkAdaptor/altair-1250-map/+/22775/11/liblegato/fa_fd.c#372.  But for now we need two as liblegato/fcntl.c handles sockets, this handles files & fifos.

commits.commitMessage:
Implement le_fd_Fcntl()

This implements le_fd_Fcntl() with an interface that matches fcntl()
to allow turning a non-blocking socket into blocking (and visa-versa).

This is required as downloader socket needs to be blocking on RTOS, but
is created as non-blocking in generic code.

Resolves: LE-11271
Change-Id: I0be884adca7854ce5f6f17700303f97c96512275
commits.subject: Implement le_fd_Fcntl()

comments.message: we should return 0 too if FifoRead is called with count = 0

Ok, so I guess here we should instead have:

    else if (!count || closed)
According to read manpage EAGAIN should be return only in NONBLOCK mode
You should only get here in non-block mode (once above condition is fixed).  Could add LE_ASSERT(filePtr->flags & FNONBLOCK) I guess.

commits.commitMessage:
Switch service ready notification to event group

Use an event group for service ready notification on FreeRTOS
as it uses less memory than a semaphore.

comments.message: I feel like this should be defined in fa_messagingLocal.h rather than here.

Can't go in fa_messagingLocal.h as that file is not included by legato.h, just messagingLocal.c specifically.  Would need to create a new messagingLocal.h in frameworkAdaptor/include, which seems like overkill for just one line.  Similar to above lines which maybe more properly go in a signal.h and time.h.

commits.commitMessage:
Add heap inspector to Codescape

This script can be run in a Codescape script region in order to inspect
the state of the heap.  Note that it can be slow at reloading if there
are lots of heap allocations, so it should probably be turned off when
single-stepping and then run when needed.

This script requires that the binary be built with SWI_HEAP_TRACE
turned on.

Resolves: LE-10940
Change-Id: Ifec7eaf7eec6716d552bd99b9e6ca13e31e832b9
commits.subject: Add heap inspector to Codescape

to be sent afterwards.

commits.commitMessage:
Refactor fd implementation to better match POSIX behaviour.

There were some incompatibilities between the original fd implementation
and POSIX behaviour for the equivalent functions, which was leading to
suprising bugs.  This reworks the fd implementation to support POSIX
semantics.

Resolves: LE-10393
Change-Id: I57cab35221f3cf036be499b5d7056dd893be5678
commits.subject: Refactor fd implementation to better match POSIX behaviour.

comments.message: Do we want to commit this permanently?
Do we want this to change to debug permanently?
stdbool.h is already included by the common legato.h
But this legato.h is included before the common legato.h so we need to include stdbool.h here as well to use bool type in any of the headers below.
no check about the validity of bufPtr?
no check about the validity of bufPtr?

an "if" is enough, no? 
if we're opening the read end we eventually need to wait the write end and vice versa. but we'll never wait for both.

EINVAL seems more appropriate since if it appears I don't guess that a retry will help ...
And when we are in this case I'm not sure that it is necessary to call uxQueueMessagesWaiting() below.
Actually a FATAL could be fine, no?

EINVAL is incorrect -- EINVAL says the arguments are wrong, whereas we get here if there's no data available in the buffer.  I chose EAGAIN since that error indicates a return due to no data being available on the FIFO, although that should only be returned if the file is non-blocking, which we don't support in FIFOs.

What about replacing with continue; and a warning?  This will also cover the case where FreeRTOS is configured to not allow suspending forever.

if you want to manage multiple waiters I think you need to wait that all waiters have read the data before emptying the queue in line 284. Otherwise I don't understand how it can work?
And the signal will be done by FreeRTOS xQueue management so I don't understand why we need to use Legato signal ?
fwupdate and packageDownloader don't use legato monitoring ...

If you have multiple readers on a FIFO, it's random which reader will get which data.  Each character will only be read by one reader.  Not often useful in practice, but it's in here for compatibility with POSIX FIFO behaviour.

This is written for the general case, not just for existing users.  This way if anyone does a fdMonitor on an RTOS FIFO, their code will work as expected.  The end goal of LegatoRTOS is to be generally useful, not just for hl78 product.
FreeRTOS documentation recommends to use xQueueSendToBack
How do you make the difference between the read end close and a normal read?
After pushing an item to the queue, FifoWrite() will check if there are any readers.
FreeRTOS documentation recommends to use xQueueSendToBack

commits.commitMessage:
[LegatoRTOS] Set LE_FS_PATH_MAX_LEN accordingly to FS limitations

Remove the prefix size from LE_FS_PATH_MAX_LEN

Resolves: LE-10717
Change-Id: I10aedb78c3a5627e79bb726dd0ab727ddcb0c23b
commits.subject: [LegatoRTOS] Set LE_FS_PATH_MAX_LEN accordingly to FS limitations

comments.message: not convinced by this include but no other idea for the moment

I would just hard-code LE_FS_PATH_MAX_LEN to a number slightly less than FS_MAX_PATH_SIZE-FS_PREFIX_SIZE and put a comment.  Making this value smaller than FS_PATH_MAX_SIZE-FS_PREFIX_SIZE is actually good (in a way) as it lets us change the prefix without risk of breaking existing code.

Otherwise maybe promote the prefix to this file.  I think it's better than including an internal header (as you are doing now), but I don't like promoting the prefix up here.
Ok for the hard coded value since I don't like to promote the prefix here since basically the le_fs api don't need to be aware about the prefix usage.

What is slightly? :) Because we don't have much room for handling since the max length from libFS is 50 ...
I propose to keep 10 characters for the prefix.
waiting answer from Altair to know if \0 is include or not in these length (case 17818)

I guess this variable is not needed, and we can just use FS_PREFIX_DATA_PATH.  Or at least it should be

    const char* fsPrefixArray = FS_PREFIX_DATA_PATH;

commits.commitMessage:
[LegatoRTOS] Avoid memory fragmentation in le_fs

Resolves: LE-10648
Change-Id: I1bcda0244190abb1646a678d8b10ea6a85e6a2c7
commits.subject: [LegatoRTOS] Avoid memory fragmentation in le_fs

comments.message: Maybe add a note that you *must* release the buffer within the same function, or you risk a deadlock.

Move Lock() to before the first CallocPath().  Otherwise you can get a deadlock if 6 threads get past the first Calloc(), they will all get stuck at the second.

Not very likely, but if it ever occurred it would be very hard to debug.
Since le_fs_Move() takes lock before alloc, you need to do the same here.
When addressing above comment, also need to reverse order of lock and release here.
Now need to move unlock below last ReleasePath().

You should pass in pathSize, which needs to be the size of the pathPtr buffer, to ensure you don't overflow the buffer.  As is there's no check to ensure the buffer being passed in is large enough to hold the path.
Since a newly allocated buffer is returned, this parameter is no longer needed.

Patch Set 3:

The problem at hand, described in LE-10526, comes from the fact that:
1 - platform only offers read operation 1 byte at a time on serial data line,
2 - documented behaviour of fdMonitor API (reporting POLLIN event every time there's data left to be read) is currently not well suited to the need of the product.

Maybe we should document this specific constraint for RTOS instead of trying to stick to fdMonitor API behaviour no matter what.

What do you think ?

commits.commitMessage:
Report only first byte and remaining data when reading from data port

Application reads in loop when notified of available data, so there
should be no need to report an event for every byte received on data
port.

Resolves: LE-10526
Change-Id: I675c1cde0f651dad13ab568ea081f28b3e265813
commits.subject: Report only first byte and remaining data when reading from data port

comments.message: What happens if the read only reads part of the data?  E.g. the buffer is smaller than the amount of data available?
This change looks good, but I expect you need to add code to DataPortRead to re-signal port event if there is still data available.
Not sure this is necessary since the application is expected to read until le_fd_Read() returns 0 to notify there's no more data left.
@Keith I'm not sure that it is the case under linux with read and poll/epoll? I guess that there'll be another notification only if new data are received, no?

Still, according to our documentation fdMonitor should notify if read is called and data is still available to be read.  If I remember correctly Andrew had to go through and add a number of extra SignalPortEvents() as the product and/or QA team were testing some corner cases.

I think it is hazardous to release the lock here.
It will be better to release it only when you return (line 1175 and at the end of the function).
If we leave le_fd_Read without notification but with isXferInProgress set to true none notification will be sent on the next reception.

commits.commitMessage:
Rework management of CMUX static devices

This should increase maintainability and avoid a bug where unsolicited
commands where sent multiple times regardless of the underlying
device's state.

Resolves: LE-9924
Change-Id: I58d4beabad7a5bc3f8c80f4a42f58b09f1fa302c
commits.subject: Rework management of CMUX static devices

comments.message: Maybe we want to call this structure differently - maybe something like PortData. It (to me) represents a port that contains 2 devices and it is more than just a static cfg, as in run time, we save data like serialMode and serialSwitchHandle. Just for clarity reasons.
MAy be nice to use an enum to fix this value
May be good to check the allowed range for index and fdType
what about using NUM_ARRAY_MEMBERS macro instead ?
This causes a crash at runtime, need to look into it before committing the change.

Crash issue was between keyboard and chair :).

Done
I don't think you need a terminating entry in this array.  If you remove it, then you should be able to use NUM_ARRAY_MEMBERS() for iterating in CreateStaticDevices().

commits.commitMessage:
Enable gcc optimization flag in debug build

Debug builds are currently done without any GCC optimization, which
unfortunately causes some timing issues at runtime on RTOS (preventing
usage of debug logs and AVC dtls connection for instance).
As a tradeoff, this enables GCC optimization flag -0s in debug builds
to allow usage of debug logs without hindering AVC connectivity.

Resolves: LE-XXXX
Change-Id: I9989b5c57fc94030701c281b4cdd7f2f221f11fa
commits.subject: Enable gcc optimization flag in debug build

comments.message: I think we should request api_fs_err.h from Altair (the file which includes these definitions), and in the mean time put these definitions in a separate header.  Error code definitions for a 3rd party component should not be hard coded in our source.

We asked them for this but they don't want because they don't have the right to do it if I well understood. For them theirs API return 0 if OK and not 0 if NOK, that's all ...

I can put it in other file if you prefer but I'm not sure that we can use the name api_ifs_err.h? What is the right place to put it?

And I guess they don't want to put some of these definitions in either libfs.h or osal.h either (where they have a bunch of other FS definitions).

Speaking of rights -- thinking about it I don't think we should be copying this entire table from their documentation as we don't have rights to do that either.  I think it would be OK/better to just include the definitions we need but use our own name and comment string.

If we have an exhaustive list of the definitions we need, trimming the enum might be clearer.

As far as the name / comments, I have no objection to use the same as the webpage as the page is accessible publicly and we do not use any source code.
Actually, I see a risk modifying the comments : if the reformulation is not as precise as the original comment, maybe we would misinterpret some error codes.
So unless we have time to find new names and accurate comments, I would keep the same ones.
In fact we have a HCC licence for the older GSM-R products. It is not the same version than Altair but the error are the same. Sevan, do you know if we have the right to use it for HL78 product?

Checked : as Altair is paying and using the HCC licence, we are covered.
We can keep the list as is.

I'm concerned on this point as we did not receive this list from Altair, and they have told us only to check not error (0) or error (non 0).

See email thread for continuation.
We should add locking around here and take the same lock in le_fs_Open().  On Linux rename is atomic, so I think when we're using le_fs functions only it should look like le_fs_Move() is atomic too.

Instead, what about using libFS_filelength(destPathLocalPtr) to determine if destination exists.  If it does, move it aside before calling libFS_mv().  This way we should be able to avoid error code issue entirely.

Change-Id: Ib1d60f167b1450a1cb55c52b3be5dc165cc36a45
commits.subject: Implement CMUX adaptation

comments.message: Could be an enum, but I decided to go for int, given that FD_MAX_DEVICE_NUM has to be multiple (2) FD_MAX_SERIAL_PORTS - so I though it was cleaner.
This can probably be much smaller than PATH_MAX.  The device names appear to be approximately 12 characters long, whereas PATH_MAX is at least 1024.

What about setting the port mode directly into the devObjPtr context ?

Not sure the localPortId is useful actually

I prefer it the way it is.  I think it is better to separate the virtual device, which is opened as either a data device or an AT device, from the virtual port underneath, which can be switched back and forth between data and AT modes.

Agree with Andrew - serial port mode is a property of serial port, not the property of (virtual) device. After all, it is how it was originally designed (but we had only one instance
until now)
Should be a const char * (-1 in the legato/ review).

I'm not sure that the size should be changed here, just because someone could specify an arbitrary name for le_fd_MkFifo(), which could be long.  The reason for making the name in DeviceStaticCfg smaller is that we have a better idea of what the bounds are.
You don't need this function any more.

commits.commitMessage:
Trigger initial data port POLLOUT on enable, too

Previously the initial POLLOUT event on the data port was triggered
only when an FD monitor was created.  Changes in the AT server and port
service stopped destroying and re-creating the monitor, and instead
started disabling and enabling it.

This patch causes the POLLOUT to be issued when the monitor is
(re)enabled as well as when it is created.

Also ensure all FD monitors receive relevant POLLOUT event when one is
issued.

Resolves: LE-10474
Change-Id: Ifd8ee56e1a400e47163cfd0023537634ad5aed32
commits.subject: Trigger initial data port POLLOUT on enable, too

commits.commitMessage:
Enable gcc optimization flag in debug build

Debug builds are currently done without any GCC optimization, which
unfortunately causes some timing issues at runtime on RTOS (preventing
usage of debug logs and AVC dtls connection for instance).
As a tradeoff, this enables GCC optimization flag -0s in debug builds
to allow usage of debug logs without hindering AVC connectivity.

Resolves: LE-XXXX
Change-Id: I9989b5c57fc94030701c281b4cdd7f2f221f11fa

commits.commitMessage:
Disable fdMonitor immediately when deleting.

When deleting fdMonitors on RTOS deleting the fdMonitor structure
itself may be deferred until any pending events have been processed
to avoid dereferencing a freed pointer and to avoid recycling
a safe ref before all references to that safe ref are removed.

However no new events should be generated on an fdMonitor
immediately when it is deleted, so on delete remove it from
the active fdMonitor list and disable all active events
so no new events will be received and all pending events
will be dropped.

Also in event loop ignore all fdMonitors with no active
events.

Resolves: LE-10398
Change-Id: I76b8c02e7b5a924b7a6b98656dee77570532b231
commits.subject: Disable fdMonitor immediately when deleting.

Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

See comment by Andrew.  I think the implementation of le_fd_Dup() should be reviewed.  Currently it is a simple stub that just returns the input file descriptor, but that seems wrong and likely to lead to this kind of issues.

Patch Set 1:

I totally agree with you. If we want a generic implementation we will implement a better le_fd_Dup to avoid the weird correction in le_fd_Close. But keep in mind that the only use of the fifo and the le_fd_Dup is for the fwupdate. If you think that it is necessary to spent many time to implement it fully, I suggest that we create a ticket for this and go forward with this current implementation. What is your feeling about this?

Patch Set 1:

> I totally agree with you. If we want a generic implementation we
 > will implement a better le_fd_Dup to avoid the weird correction in
 > le_fd_Close. But keep in mind that the only use of the fifo and the
 > le_fd_Dup is for the fwupdate. If you think that it is necessary to
 > spent many time to implement it fully, I suggest that we create a
 > ticket for this and go forward with this current implementation.
 > What is your feeling about this?

It needs to be done right, the first time.  The idea of "we'll accept wrong behaviour because it works well enough for this case" doesn't work in my experience.  This tends to lead to subtle bugs, and either an increasing Jenga tower-like pile of "fixes"; or needing to fix the underlying issue at a later point anyway.  So I strongly disagree with any workaround which does not fix the underlying issue -- le_fd API does not work the way POSIX file descriptors are expected to work.
Patch Set 2: Patch Set 1 was rebased

Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

Code review comments still not addressed.

Patch Set 2:

> It needs to be done right, the first time. The idea of "we'll accept wrong behaviour because it works well enough for this case" doesn't work in my experience. This tends to lead to subtle bugs, and either an increasing Jenga tower-like pile of "fixes"; or needing to fix the underlying issue at a later point anyway. So I strongly disagree with any workaround which does not fix the underlying issue -- le_fd API does not work the way POSIX file descriptors are expected to work.

Ok but currently it's not the first delivery. le_fd has been delivered few months ago.
Moreover since the beginning this API has been mostly developed to mainly meet our expectations for the HL78. So I'm not sure that it is the time to challenge it now?
But if the rework to a full POSIX API is compliant with the planning, I'm OK :)

commits.commitMessage:
Only trigger lwip semaphore when in eventLoop's select().

When in select() from event loop, we need to trigger lwip semaphore
if an event arrives to exit out early so we can handle the event.
However this semaphore *must* *not* be triggered in other situations
as it can interfere with the internal operation of lwip.

Modify event loop code to check if we're in eventLoop select() before
triggering this semaphore.

Resolves: LE-10224
Change-Id: I59df646579789dc4e52aa55442ac58d297038992
commits.subject: Only trigger lwip semaphore when in eventLoop's select().

commits.commitMessage:
Return error codes when sending unsolicited commands

By design atSwitchApi fails when there are no client registered to receive an
unsolicited command sent through AtCmdSendUnsolCmd(). Consequently error codes
were not returned at Legato level when calling that function.

This patch returns error codes when sending unsolicited commands and filters out
the case where no client are actually registered.

Resolves: LE-10183
Change-Id: If342692ae001aa3d8f673665cc1b0577d2a67c7b
commits.subject: Return error codes when sending unsolicited commands

commits.commitMessage:
Rewrite timer code to use select()/semaphore timeout.

Previously the timer code was using Altair timers, which involved
a bunch of external resources being created & used.  However select()
and semaphore wait functions being used in the event loop take a timeout(),
so instead use this timeout to wake the thread when a timer has expired.

This obsoletes the need to manage Altair timers, so resolves any
issue of Altair timer lifetime not being managed correctly.

Resolves: LE-10020
Change-Id: I2d8dcd631ea9143490d204262a236c7050077e26
commits.subject: Rewrite timer code to use select()/semaphore timeout.

[legatoRTOS] Port mkfifo in AVC: add a pseudo SIGPIPE

- Modify FIFO_BUFFER_SIZE from 4192 to 4096
- Correct some LOG format specifiers

Resolves: LE-10106

commits.subject: [legatoRTOS] Port mkfifo in AVC: add a pseudo SIGPIPE

comments.message: What happens if read end is reopened?  It looks like queue will still be full, so writer will still treat fifo as closed.

The queue will be reset when the write end will be closed.

Keep in mind that the implementation is mainly done for the AVC usage.

But perhaps it could be solve by adding a queue reset in the EPIPE case in FifoWrite.
This is just to satisfy my own curiosity, but why did the magic ID change?
This is to avoid setting the MSB, thus allowing us to test the magic ID against negative values.

I don't know if we have an official policy on this, but I'm not a fan of loops with no body like this.  All it takes is forgetting a semicolon, and suddenly xTaskResumeAll() is being executed in a loop.  I prefer a body with a comment saying "do nothing" to make the intent clear, but even just a pair of braces at the end is better.

commits.commitMessage:
Reset buffer offset when opening device in DATA mode

On device opening le_fd data buffer seekOffset pointer is reset but
not the offset pointer. This causes a bug where the service reports a
bad count of available data.
This patch resets the le_fd buffer offset when opening device in DATA
mode.

Resolves: LE-10079
Change-Id: Iac5756db62020b00dc2578dfe57d4975d3e5b666
commits.subject: Reset buffer offset when opening device in DATA mode

commits.commitMessage:
Reset buffer content once data is read on serial line

The data buffer was not reset after reading on the serial line through
le_fd_Read(), which causes a bug where the same data can be read in
loop.
This patch fixes the issue by resetting the buffer content once data
is read on the serial line.

Resolves: LE-10008
Change-Id: If553ab4ca521d3a49bf896a436361a37a385251c
commits.subject: Reset buffer content once data is read on serial line

commits.commitMessage:
Add ioctl requests to switch device to AT/DATA mode

To switch between AT and DATA mode through le_port_SetCommandMode()
and le_port_SetDataMode(), portService component needs to send a
corresponding request to the device through le_fd service.
This patch adds LE_FD_SET_CMD_MODE and LE_FD_SET_DATA_MODE ioctl
requests to le_fd to switch the device to AT/DATA mode
accordingly. Additionally, this patch also fixes logical port id that
is passed to serialMngrToggleApi() when switching from DATA to AT mode
when first opening the device.

Resolves: LE-10009
Change-Id: I99d74511f745c677534c299e65122f76f9a291dd
commits.subject: Add ioctl requests to switch device to AT/DATA mode

commits.commitMessage:
Support waiting on multiple FDs in event loop

Previously the main loop would wait on a semaphore for events
to be signalled in the event loop, and (the) file descriptor
would be waited on in an auxillary thread.  However this is wasteful
(as it requires an extra thread), and cannot easily support waiting
on multiple file descriptors.

However LWIP supports using a per-thread semaphore for signalling
lwip_select().  When this semaphore is signalled, lwip_select()
will wakeup and return, similar to if the process had received a
signal on Linux.  So modify Altair code to use per-thread
select semaphores, and then replace the semaphore in the event
loop with the lwip_select call directly.

Note: Currently timers are set up to create an extra thread when
they expire.  The extra thread then queues an event in the main
thread.  Since select() takes a timeout parameter, this extra
thread can be eliminated by making the timeout the time until
the next timer expiry.  Then when select returns() it should
check against the timer list and queue any expired timers in
the main thread.

Resolves: LE-9842
Change-Id: If9f0c923b46f6dfe5b86cf60f4181bcaa755f04e
commits.subject: Support waiting on multiple FDs in event loop

comments.message: it should be fine to add a test to check if LWIP_NETCONN_SEM_PER_THREAD is defined ?
If I well understood if the flag is not define it will not work, no?

Yes.  But we don't usually have separate checks to ensure 3rd party libraries are configured correctly -- e.g. we don't check if TLS is enabled in FreeRTOS, HTTP being enabled in libcurl, etc.

This is Altair-specific code too, so we don't have to worry about confusing (eventual) 3rd party developers.
There is a check about TLS in pthread_extra.c for example. But I understand your opinion and it is not a blocking point anyway.

commits.commitMessage:
Create pool inspector for CodeScape debugger

This creates a memory pool for the CodeScape debugger which displays
information similar to "inspect pools" on Linux.

As RTOS memory is smaller than on Linux, this tool will also show
memory pool overhead.

Resolves: LE-9837
Change-Id: I2de892acb7c5bcb5b59dfd6b0a07ef0d90d90e94
commits.subject: Create pool inspector for CodeScape debugger

commits.commitMessage:
Re-enable static memory pool allocation flag

Following the change to move Legato RTOS code to static memory pools,
this patch re-enables the LE_MEM_VALGRIND flag that make the change
effective at runtime, thus avoiding a system crash at startup.
Enable the flag in custom_os/legato.h instead of le_build_config.h to
keep it specific to RTOS.

Resolves: LE-9742
Change-Id: I28930865f61dc4a9491594a137935a98970719a1
commits.subject: Re-enable static memory pool allocation flag

commits.commitMessage:
Set guard band size to 4-bytes on RTOS

Overflows are generally either large, or 1 item.  So on RTOS use only
a single 4-byte guard band to reduce memory usage.

Resolves: LE-9497
Change-Id: Ib2607c6661ccd2ac8cd7f76abcad5c3c07882bb2
commits.subject: Set guard band size to 4-bytes on RTOS

commits.commitMessage:
Move code used on Legato RTOS to static pools.

To make the amount of memory Legato uses more visible, move all
dynamically-created pools to statically created pools.  This ensures
the amount of memory used in pools will be visible at compile time.

Resolves: LE-9464
Change-Id: Iaab69476b843b80e5ab69d7e1c1be7df25436392
commits.subject: Move code used on Legato RTOS to static pools.

commits.commitMessage:
Fix switching from data mode to AT mode

Closing the le_fd DATA port device should result in switching to the
ATSERVER device at platform level which is not the case because the
wrong logical serial port number is being passed to the platform API
to toggle the switch. As a consequence the receive callback function
registered for data mode can still be called by the platform, which
induces a crash due to the processing of the received data while in AT
mode.
This patch fixes the switch from data to AT processing by passing the
correct logical serial port number to the platform toggle API.

Resolves: LE-9506
Change-Id: Ie886771c2472cb299f41968f0735987b3c044a25
commits.subject: Fix switching from data mode to AT mode

comments.message: EBUSY is not an error code expected for open
EBUSY is not an error code expected for open

I wasn't trying to replicate the erno behaviour stated by the manpages since we are not on a POSIX system: I picked a value that would just make sense if catched as a reason for error by the user.
Anyway, will replace with EACCES which should be another sensible value from the manpage.
EBUSY is not an error code expected for open
EBUSY is not an error code expected for close

why returning an error in errno since it's not managed in upper function?
I fyou to do that you must update the prototype to have a return value and managing the error in le_fd_Close.

commits.commitMessage:
Switch from pthread_cond to FreeRTOS semaphore.

There is a race in Altair's pthread_cond implementation, so switch
to the FreeRTOS Semaphore implementation instead.

Resolves: LE-9447
Change-Id: I5140e6c673bc777ab4bb5caf111c670b33e56e60
commits.subject: Switch from pthread_cond to FreeRTOS semaphore.

comments.message: did you create a bug about it?

With Altair?  No -- I can't really isolate to a good test case to give to them.  

I _think_ the issue is when waiting the internal mutex is unlocked, then timer is created, then task is suspended. When signalling, mutex is locked & unlocked, then task is resumed.  If wait thread switches out between unlock of internal mutex and task suspend, then signal switches in, it will not resume the waiting thread (since it's not yet suspended), but will still be removed from waiting task list.  

In order to fix you need to unlock mutex & suspend as an atomic operation, but no such operation exists, so cond needs to be completely rewritten in a different manner (I think).

Since we have a workaround I thought I wouldn't bother them with something that isn't critical.
if *sem is NULL we need to return -1 with an errno
Which is why we check NULL == SEM on line 33.
do not assume the value of pdPASS and pdFAIL
do not assume the value of pdPASS and pdFAIL
do not assume the value of pdPASS and pdFAIL

commits.commitMessage:
Return error code when passing invalid fd to fcntl()

The fcntl() function implemented by Legato stack to fill missing POSIX
compatibility gaps does not return an error code when passed a file
descriptor which is -1, as a consequence its callers cannot catch the
error accordingly.
This patch returns an error code when fcntl is passed a -1 file
descriptor.

Resolves: LE-9451
Change-Id: I52053a3de88e723a0394c0536e229812894b9e2d
commits.subject: Return error code when passing invalid fd to fcntl()

commits.commitMessage:
Add serial port support to le_fd API

To allow switching between at command and data over the serial line,
Legato must provide a way to plug into the underlying serial port API
provided by the platform.
This patch adds such serial port support through le_fd API.

Resolves: LE-8184
Change-Id: I39f6b951da0e038815640f8c2cc74ac76a070d4a
commits.subject: Add serial port support to le_fd API

comments.message: The code is in the frameworkAdaptor. No need to put CUSTOM_OS. FD_SEM_LOCK is more meaningful

The idea behind CUSTOM_OS_LOCK semantic is to let the reader guess that this lock relies on a mechanism from the OS (xSemaphoreTake/xSemaphoreGive), instead of relying on a mechanism from Legato (this is purposely not using le_mutex_Lock).
Unused at the moment, may be removed.
could be better to use an union to avoid to consume too much resources ?

Anthony had the same suggestion and I agreed at first then I realised that atServer and dataPort devices use the same set of members  + "isDataBufFull" and "seekOffset" which dataPort uses in addition to the rest so I didn't use an union...
Total size of the union will be the size of the biggest struct inside the union so we will not save much on memory space for now but you're right: with the addition of fifo devices it may makes sense to use a union now and it will ease reading this DeviceObj struct at least.

Will use union.
Because we need mutal exclusion with DataPortRxFunc which is called from a RTOS (non-Legato) thread.
why unlocking here as you relock just after ?
You're right, don't know what I was thinking about....
It could be nice to have a functions pointers table, but it is fine like that right now.
Ok, will try to add that before final version of this work.
is it really useful to unlock here? Why not waiting the end of the function ?
How to we warn the user that some data have to be read (i.e. fdMonitor) ?

I think I forgot the "notify the user that data is available" part :-).
Question: do we report an event here *every time* we receive 1 char ?
the pointers must be updated and the copy must be done under lock.
the defintion is in fdMonitor.h so no need to declare it here.
the function is declared as LE_SHARED in fa_fdMonitor.c so I think that its protoytpe should be in an include file.

Currently this file depends on some applications being installed on the system.  This isn't good -- liblegato is at a lower layer than the applications, so should not depend on them.  

This could be resolved by (for example):

1) AtServer & DataPort functions could be moved to the application, then 

2) Change this to an external function (like le_fd_RegisterDevice(name, Open, Read, Write, Ioctl)), which is then called from the application startup to notify the fd abstraction layer that a new device is available.

I think I get your point but the idea of this layer is to be a wrapper for system specificities and what you are calling "applications" is actually part of the system from my point of view (if we are both talking about Altair's atSwitchApi and serialMngrApi here).
Moreover, for DataPort we don't have any backward dependency on the platformServices unlike the atServer contraption with its le_atServer_Get* symbols (issue we're currently tracking with LE-9364 thanks to you).

If you still think things should not be done as proposed here please open an improvement tracker to rework this once we deliver a first working version of Data mode control API.

commits.commitMessage:
Fix AT command response not received on AT port

In order for the atSwitch to parse AT command correctly some control
characters need to be inserted at the end of each step of the
processing.
This patch fixes an issue where the reponse to an AT command sent from
the AT port is "ERROR" instead of the actual expected response to the
command, due to the ending control character sent to the atSwitch
being '\r' instead of '\n'.

Resolves: LE-9430
Change-Id: I856522c4f542319302020972c371addd0568fda6
commits.subject: Fix AT command response not received on AT port

commits.commitMessage:
Weaken le_atServer_Get* symbols to workaround dependency

A design issue in atServer RTOS code created a dependency from the
framework toward the platform service.
This patch weakens the symbols toward which the framework has this
backward dependency until atServer code is reworked to fix the issue.

Resolves: LE-9364
Change-Id: Ib6c85e15c1abb8d2f3c18067cab20348ecebce3d
commits.subject: Weaken le_atServer_Get* symbols to workaround dependency

commits.commitMessage:
Turn on GCC size optimization for Legato code

Previously only parts of the binary were optimized for size.  Running
with

    make DEBUG=yes

will turn this optimization off and emit debug code instead.

Turning on -Os reduces the binary size by about 20%.

Resolves: LE-9376
Change-Id: I17ad9c14a91d852579a93a50f92e86a3a71b9e6f
commits.subject: Turn on GCC size optimization for Legato code

comments.message: Turning on optimization in debug mode makes JTAG debugging harder.  I think we should leave this behaviour that debug turns off optimization -- optimization is really the only difference between debug and not debug, as far as I can tell.
On RTOS it's safe to enable debug always (not just on debug builds).  Debug information will get stripped out before loading onto target anyway.

[legatoRTOS] Port mkfifo in AVC

commits.subject: [legatoRTOS] Port mkfifo in AVC

comments.message:
I thought we were going to remove this.
If we keep it inside the .c file, how do we advertise the name of the devices here that are expected to be passed to le_fd_Open() ?

Function obviously returns a pointer to the device object in the output parameter.
Please update comments accordingly.
Looks like data buffer allocation has been removed from here anyway ?

If fdCtxPtr object is no longer released then there is no need for FdRefDestructor() anymore I think.
If that's the case, please remove FdRefDestructor() and release fdCtxPtr object from the hashmap object here.
Please platform name references, I shouldn't have put it in in the first place.
Any particular reason for this size?  4096 or 8192 would seem more natural to me.
No it is a "ramdom" value to avoid to consume too much memory but without fragmenting too much the data transfert
I think you need to lock here for case of multiple readers.
I don't know these part comes from the original code.
No because the device is not destroyed.
Ok, so "static devices (ie. atServer, atClient and soon to be dataPort)" are never destroyed because the code always returns the same fd, but what about fifos on RTOS ?

it is the same thing. Once created the device remains.
I don't know how a fifo can be destroyed once created by mkfifo. In our context (packageDownloader.c) it seems there is only the creation.
In fact the way to destroy a fifo is to do an unlink. This is not done in the package downlaoder currently.

commits.commitMessage:
Add RTOS stubs.

Add some stub functions for RTOS:
- lwip does not support the gai_strerror() function, so add a basic
  implementation based on the FreeBSD error strings.
- Altair does not support setting clock time, so stub clock_settime() to
  always return error and set errno to EPERM.

Resolves: LE-7588
Change-Id: Ia1f3d15a94038a9c8a71c5ca7524a5b4bbd20024
commits.subject: Add RTOS stubs.

comments.message: if the caller has a typically legato error management (i.e do a FATAL) I'm not sure that it's a good idea to return an error, no?

Call should fail because time is not being set.  It's responsibility of caller to handle error appropriately.  LE_FATAL() is only recommended if program cannot logically continue after failure of call -- in which case not returning error here just turns a fatal into undetected logic error, which is worse.

commits.commitMessage:
Implement RTOS specific le_fd API

Following the rework of the atServer, this patch implements the le_fd
API that abstracts read and write operations from/to the modem device
controlled by a vendor specific software component.
Additionally, the file descriptors exposed by the API are now monitored
through the fdMonitor framework service.

Resolves: LE-8756
Change-Id: I3edc0406a2e203f110822437a93743279868c532
commits.subject: Implement RTOS specific le_fd API

comments.message: The buffer size is quite big and le_mem do not return the freed memory to the system, it stays in the pool, which might be a problem if the system needs it when we are not using it here.
Ok, I see why you wanted a type instead of an enum :).

Typo, I changed the name a couple of times and forgot to update it here.

Done
missing description and you should create a type

Do we really need a type here ?
For instance, t o open an atServer dvice with the API the user is expected to do:
le_fd_Open("atServer", 0, NULL);

So it's the device name that is really used, and this enum is primarily used in the implementation to avoid parsing the device  name which is a string. You may be right about using a type instead though, let me know if there is something here that I missed or overlooked.

Description will be added.
ne prefix is needed if it's only used in this file, simply call ir AT_COMMAND_MAX_BYTES
we should give the address of the pointer to get the pointer to use
using a getter function would be safer

This prefix is useless (except in the directory name), it may be removed (everywhere)

BTW, it doesn't follow the coding rules (it would be Alt1250Device_t)
Prefix is needed to avoid name clash with Device_t from le_dev. Will change to Alt1250Device_t.
Maybe related to socket monitoring only, move down below if that's the case.

This won't work for atClient which may have multiple fd opened at once.
Find a way to get the fdMonitor safe ref from the given fd.

Name already exists, will be LEGATO_FA_FD_H_INCLUDE_GUARD instead.

Done

I would prefer to not have the mention of a platform in the code. The directory mentions the platform. This is useless and may be wrong in the next Altair platform.
Tristan, what is your opinion ?
It looks it is a fd, so better name this AtServerFd
What about storing current position in the buffer, so you don't need to call strlen() here?  strlen() is relatively slow -- O(n) in used buffer space.

The service does not own that particular buffer, so I didn't find it useful to keep track of its offset.
Will factorize that code to save optimize a bit.
Should you set errno if returning -1 to match errno that would be set by write()?
I hope so, as we use it elsewhere.
So will this be implemented in a future patch?  If so, it might be slick to have SOCKET & FILESYSTEM as separate types so you can call lwip_write() or fs write depending on the fd type.
Yes, that is one of the ideas behind the design of this service: would be nice to have a single abstraction for all different types of fd on the system. We just need to find the time to do it :).
I've created LE-9183 to track this issue.

In this case, should copy in as many bytes as there is remaining buffer space, and return number of bytes written, unless no space is available in which case should return -1 and set errno = EAGAIN.  This matches the Linux behaviour of write(), so our code *should* be written to handle that behaviour.  This is assuming fd is configured as non-blocking.
Done, except for the errno part (need to check if supported on OpenRTOS).
even if unused I'm not sure that it is a good idea to have the value

That's a mistake, thanks for noticing it.

Done
this is not a pointer but an array
IsDeviceExist as it returns a bool ?
there isn't an include file with these definitions ?

I didn't want to expose these functions that are defined by the Altair specific atServer component.
Design wise, le_atServer_alt1250 code should be part of le_fd RTOS implementation I think, but I couldn't find a way to do that because of the component initialization. 
As a consequence, declaring those extern functions is an attempt to keep the design as close to the original idea as possible.

commits.commitMessage:
[OpenRTOS] Add implementation of Altair 1250 le_fs

Currently only the following API are implemented:
- le_fs_Open with the flag combinations:
	- O_WRONLY | O_CREAT | O_TRUNC
	- O_RDWR | O_CREAT | O_TRUNC
	- O_RDWR
	- O_RDWR | O_CREAT
	- O_APPEND | O_WRONLY | O_CREAT
	- O_APPEND | O_RDWR | O_CREAT
- le_fs_Close
- le_fs_Read
- le_fs_Write (need to call le_fs_Close before any other operation)
- le_fs_GetSize
- le_fs_Delete
- le_fs_Exists
- le_fs_Move

Resolves: LE-8690
Change-Id: Ib88af0f49c9e871ecff069aa08c0db1618e2330e
commits.subject: [OpenRTOS] Add implementation of Altair 1250 le_fs

comments.message: Might we want to access outside this area (e.g. Altair config files)?  Maybe add just e: to paths, and only if a drive letter is not specified in the path.
Ignore this, I see this is how Linux works as well.
LE_FS_SYNC should be ignored since your ConvertFlagsToMode() function doesn't support it.
The problem is this introduces a race -- if file is deleted between when you check if it exists, and opening the file.  No way around it though I guess.
Unlike when using read(), I don't think this is necessary here as C standard library should do buffering, reread short, etc.
Maybe track if O_SYNC was included in flags, and only do this if O_SYNC was set?  fflush() is usually _very_ slow.
Do you need to make sure le_fs directory  isn't removed?

commits.commitMessage:
[DO NOT MERGE][STUDY] Porting effort of ConfigTree without IPC

The ConfigTree API needs to be ported to RTOS due to the
AirVantageConnector & DataConnectionService components relying on it.
This API seems highly dependent on IPC, which means it most
probably won't be portable as it is without IPC.
In order to evaluate the feasability of porting ConfigTree API before
having IPC, this patch adds the following changes:

- import configTree Linux core implementation (ie. without API
  implementation code) into liblegato/configTree/.

Starting from here, the idea is to make the necessary changes to build
the configTree not as a daemon (which requires IPC availability) but
as an integral part of the framework (either in liblegato as it is
shown here, or someplace else to be defined).

Related: LE-7548
Change-Id: Idf119dada48c90b97001bbd91f939c410366f045
commits.subject: [DO NOT MERGE][STUDY] Porting effort of ConfigTree without IPC

commits.commitMessage:
[DO NOT MERGE][STUDY] Porting effort of ConfigTree without IPC

The ConfigTree API needs to be ported to RTOS due to the
AirVantageConnector & DataConnectionService components relying on it.
This API seems highly dependent on IPC, which means it most
probably won't be portable as it is without IPC.
In order to evaluate the feasability of porting ConfigTree API before
having IPC, this patch adds the following changes:

- import configTree.h interface from le_cfg_interface.h generated
  file,
- implement configTree.c based on aforementioned interface by reusing
  configTreeApi.c initial implementation where possible,
- stub and isolate all automatically generated functions related to
  IPC that pervade configTree code into le_cfg_stub.c,
- amend core configTree code according to the above changes.

Related: LE-7548
Change-Id: I0d7944a80dc6c2cbe99375169a04c27598c3f577
commits.subject: [DO NOT MERGE][STUDY] Porting effort of ConfigTree without IPC

commits.commitMessage:
[OpenRTOS] Add implementation of Altair 1250 functions:

 - reboot()
 - fcntl()
 - access()

Resolves: LE-7575
Change-Id: Icabde86a73e3c0bc4002e29e59b49a130bf707e7
commits.subject: [OpenRTOS] Add implementation of Altair 1250 functions:

comments.message: exit is not present in this patch ...
in this case how can we consider the ticket as treated?

It was a temporary implementation waiting information from Altair related to File permissions feature and I just got the information from Altair. They don't have file permissions feature in their lwIP implementation (I suppose a #define not set because SafeFLASH file system from HCC embedded has this feature => I'll check with Altair)
In consequence I implemented only file existence check with not file permissions feature.

I think this should treat all files as having RW permissions.

I.e.:
- If file does not exist, return -1 with errno = ENOENT
- If file exists but permission requested was X_OK, return -1 errno = EACCES
- If file exist, permission did not include X_OK, return 0.
I re-implemented the function following your advice.
in this case how can we consider the ticket as treated?

I think this is actually OK -- 0 means no flags, and I doubt lwip or fs layer supports any flags anyway.

Is F_GETFD the only ioctl used in Legato?
Please see my answer to Gaetan
I re-implemented it using the very limited implementation of this function in lwIP (only with 3 parameters and F_GETFL & F_SETFL commands with O_NONBLOCK flag having a NON POSIX value)

not sure how libFS_task_init/exit work.
Perhaps we'll need to remove them from here ...
does not work if the path is ended with a '/'

This isn't the way va_arg() works.  If there's no next argument it doesn't return 0, instead "random errors will occur" (exact quote from the man page).

Instead you should be checking if cmd == F_SETFL before calling va_arg, and if cmd == F_SETFL, assume there's another argument.
This won't return correct results if file is on a RO fs.  Do we care?

Good point. Currently we are not able to know if the file is on a RO fs. What we know is "currently" Altair provides 3 disks c:/ (RO in FLASH), d:/ (RW in FLASH) and e:/ (RW in RAM). I could check if the letter disk is not "c:\" in absolute paths but I'm not sure it is the final implementation and for relative paths it will be tricky ...

Unfortunately we don't seem to always pass a 3rd argument for F_GETFL, and it works on Linux (e.g. ./apps/platformServices/airVantageConnector/apps/test/packageDownloadHost/packageDownloadComp/fwupdateServer_stub.c:95, ./framework/liblegato/fileDescriptor.c:25).  So I think we should treat F_GETFL as a 2-argument command, and not try to get a 3rd argument in this case.
Ok. It's easier for me to implement fcntl(..., F_GETFL) or fcntl(..., F_GETFL, x) as always calling lwip_fcntl(..., F_GETFL, 0)
Should this call lwip_fcntl(fd, SETFL, 0) instead to set to non-block mode?

commits.commitMessage:
Simple local messaging for RTOS.

This is a simple in-process messaging mechanism, which queues messages
directly in the server event loop.  Message responses are indicated via
a semaphore in the message.

Resolves: LE-7549
Change-Id: I2798e5f13cd987a6bf3ef79d5ba963041bfcd5e1
commits.subject: Simple local messaging for RTOS.

commits.commitMessage:
Implement fdMonitor API for Altair 1250 MAP

Unlike the Linux implementation, fdMonitor API for Altair 1250 MAP
only monitors socket events.
Moreover, socket events monitoring is done through lwip_select() due
to LwIP being the chosen TCP/IP stack for Altair 1250 MAP.

Resolves: LE-7563
Change-Id: I48ab79972a9e46f330348c9acef61fd648b2a4b0
commits.subject: Implement fdMonitor API for Altair 1250 MAP

comments.message: Lots of boiler plate code here just to wait and report an event on a socked fd. I don't see a better way to do this though.

Not sure this is the right way to do it (safeRef shouldn't be passed around since it is owned by fdMonitor object) but I don't think there's a way to retrieve the reference through the eventLoop monitor list. Or is there a way ?

Eventually, would be nice to retrieve the fdMonitor instance from within the eventLoop instead of passing data around like this. Do we have a mechanism to retrieve a specific fdMonitor object from eventLoop code ?

This code doesn't look right:

1) How do you handle monitoring multiple FDs?
2) Needs to still wake on queued events when waiting for an FD.  This looks like if you're waiting for an FD it doesn't wake until data is available on the FD.

You're right, I indeed overlooked the points you mentioned:

1) Don't have a clean solution on how to monitor mutliple FDs right now (overlooked the fact that a single thread may be monitoring multiple FDs),
2) Since we don't have a common way to signal socket events and queued events, I'm thinking about polling for each type of event in turn until one of them occurs.

1) select() can monitor multiple FDs.  That's the purpose of the function -- or are you thinking of some other problem?
2) We can't poll.  It will completely destroy performance and power consumption.  Typical options to solve this problem would be: (1) include pipe/local socket in the select, and write a character to it when an event is received; (2) send a signal, which will cause select() to return EINTR (probably not available on RTOS).  We may also be forced to use lwip callback API and write our own BSD-socket wrapper, in which case lwip callback could potentially queue an event directly in the event loop.  There are probably other options too.
it can be interesting to deal with EAGAIN to be compliant with POSIX select behavior
I can add that if you want, but it will be dead code anyway since the only errno codes returned by lwip_select() are either ENOMEM or EBADF.
Maybe I should use the POLLIN, POLLOUT and POLLPRI semantics here instead of reinventing the wheel.

Since we do not have the equivalent of epoll to put the eventLoop to sleep until an event is ready to fire, current eventLoop implementation polls for queued events and socket events every 5 seconds.
The 5 seconds delay is arbitrary here, we may want to set it higher to have a better balance between cpu/power usage and event processing delay.

This should be taken as a quick-and-dirty solution until we have a better implementation that allows the eventLoop to sleep until an event is ready to fire (just like it works on Linux through epoll file descriptors).
you must use doxy style as below
Using an le_sem_Ref_t semaphore here seems to consistently crash OpenRTOS. I wonder if it's related to the fact that le_semaphores rely on thread that are actually separate tasks on OpenRTOS...
why we don't use legato mutex?
This helps mitigate the fact that the same event is detected continuously until the event report is actually processed.
I think that a mutex could be more appropriate, no?
you should use a define too
Why do you need a safeRef here instead of just pass pointer in param1?

I'm not sure I get your point here.
This same mechanism is used in le_fdMonitor_Enable(), le_fdMonitor_Disable(), le_fdMonitor_SetContextPtr(), le_fdMonitor_GetFd() and le_fdMonitor_Delete() to retrieve the pointer to the monitor object by looking-up its safeRef in the monitor refMap.

Do you suggest we directly pass the pointer to the object in param1 instead of passing its safeRef (thus avoiding the call to le_ref_Lookup()) ?
Yes, I'm asking about the whole mechanism.  I didn't think I needed to comment on everywhere it was used though.
Why not just call le_event_QueueFunctionToThread() directly, instead of report event -> queue function?

I tried that (and it worked) but then it made sense to me to rely on fdMon_Report() at the time.
Will use le_event_QueueFunctionToThread() instead and remove fdMon_Report() which then becomes useless.

Done

-1: If multiple sockets become available at once you may have multiple threads waiting on the same semaphore, and it's undetermined which one will wake up (with negative results).

I think there should be an event per-thread.

In the current implementation there is only one SocketMonitorHandler thread per fdMonitor object.
I think this should be addressed with regard to a rework of fdMonitor to have only one SocketMonitorHandler() for the whole system (thus monitoring socket events for multiple threads through this function).

Imagine this situation:

- SocketMonitorHandler(fdA) calls le_event_Report()
- SocketMonitorHandler(fdA) calls le_sem_Wait(EventHandlerSem)
- SocketMonitorHandler(fdB) calls le_event_Report()
- SocketMonitorHandler(fdB) calls le_sem_Wait(EventHandlerSem)
- hander for fdB is dispatched
- le_sem_Post(EventHandlerSem) is called.
- ??? which thread wakes up now?

I don't think this is necessary.  SocketMonitorThread can just go through all fdMonitors in the list and build up list of FDs to select.  As a bonus, this will remove limitation on number of fds that can be monitored on RTOS.

Ok, I think this could be addressed as a rework to have only one SocketMonitorHandler() for the whole system (thus monitoring socket events for multiple threads through this function). There's already LE-8490 opened for a rework of the eventLoop btw, maybe we could use that tracker for this.
-1: Should not create one per monitored fd, there should just be one for entire system.
Would also be part of the rework proposed above.
-1: I think you need some way in here to either wake select()ing thread.  Otherwise enabling events will not take effect until after next event is received, which would be very unexpected.

Unlike epoll(), select() does not offers a mean to update the the fd set until after an event is received.
Maybe there's a better way to do this though, in which case it should be considered part of the rework proposed above.
So fire an event through an auxiliary socket.  We discussed this technique before.

If not implemented, don't put an implementation so we get a link error.  It's better to see the link error than always get a runtime error.

I'm adding LE_FULL_API which will generate compile errors for functions which are not implemented on RTOS; when available that marking should be used for this function as well.
Ok, will try LE_FULL_API instead when available.

- reset timer field to -1 in StopTimer()

commits.subject: Add Altair MAP 1250 implementation for timer

comments.message: Ah, nevermind - this is the due to the "solo" build. Strange how that is even built.
What was wrong with the timer behaviour?
Is there a limit to the number of system timers available?
It seems to be only limited by the memory space in Altair implementation ...
This sentence doesn't really make sense anymore.
I don't think this should happen if there are no timers running.
Best to use sizeof(str) here to avoid problems if str gets resized.
Should not be using printf() in here.

What are the ramifications of this on the thread priority? If the thread has a high real-time priority, then its timers' expiries should be processed at the same real-time priority. I don't think this design works that way.
If I well understand the callback is called in privilege mode
Comment is inaccurate since it's not a FD.

Add log on Altair 1250 system

Resolves: LE-7547

commits.subject: Add log on Altair 1250 system

comments.message: I'm assuming this is in preparation for logging to a log daemon?  If possible we should avoid putting temporary strings on the stack as stack space will be limited on RTOS.

Yes.

Where do you want to put the string? It needs to be related to the current context. Otherwise there will be a reentrance problem ...
If possible I would write directly to stderr/stdout.  If not, thread local data is an alternative; although on stack is probably fine for now.

fprintf(stderr, ...) wasn't working for me.

Also this should be protected by a mutex.  Otherwise output ends up jumbled in a multithreading environment.

Here's what my logs look like now:

     DBUGapps/test/f | /home/kduramework/rtos/multi-appnwoody/uLeg/helloComponato/build/sent/greet.c Greet() 5 |ystem/app/go Hello, WorodbyeWorld/sld!

Very strange. I don't have this behavior ...
stderr works fine.
Have you made a test with the last Altair delivery? 

The log is interlaced with previous version because it is outputted in 3 times (printf, vprintf, puts).
Here, the log is outputted in 1 time so there is no problem.

Here is what are the logs look like with this version:

Initializing semaphore subsystem
Initializing event subsystem
Jan  1 00:00:00 :  DBUG | _UNKNOWN_[6] T=unknown | mem.c InitPool() 302 | Memory pool name 'framework.hashMap_refEventHandlers'
 is truncated to 'framework.hashMap_refEventHandl'
Initializing thread subsystem
Jan  1 00:00:00 :  DBUG | _UNKNOWN_[6] T=main | microSupervisor.c le_supervisor_Main() 97 | Starting app helloWorld
Jan  1 00:00:00 :  DBUG | _UNKNOWN_[6] T=main | microSupervisor.c le_supervisor_Main() 104 |  (0) Creating task helloWorld
Jan  1 00:00:00 :  DBUG | _UNKNOWN_[6] T=main | thread.c SetSchedPolicyAttr() 507 | Set scheduling policy to SCHED_OTHER for th
read 'helloWorld'.
Jan  1 00:00:00 :  DBUG | _UNKNOWN_[6] T=main | microSupervisor.c le_supervisor_Main() 131 |  (0) Starting task helloWorld
[    0.456028980] lwip_stats ready
[    0.463143560] Starting scheduler
[    0.470198300] Application compile time Oct  3 2017 08:52:01 922
[    0.483556860] at client:  active, serial interface assigned to it !!!
[    0.493527410] at client:  active, serial interface assigned to it !!!
[    0.506546640] PPP: active serial interface UART1 is assign to it
[    0.520939420] init_netifs() pppos_create was return with 0x9035afe0
e:/>Jan  1 00:00:00 :  DBUG | _UNKNOWN_[7] T=helloWorld | mem.c le_mem_ForceAlloc() 840 | Memory pool 'framework.DestructorObjs
' overflowed. Expanded to zu blocks.
Jan  1 00:00:00 :  INFO | _UNKNOWN_[7] T=helloWorld | helloWorld.c _helloComponent_COMPONENT_INIT() 5 | Hello, world.
Jan  1 00:00:00 :  DBUG | _UNKNOWN_[7] T=helloWorld | _main.c _helloWorld_Main() 18 | == Starting Event Processing Loop ==

No, I had only tested with old Altair delivery; stderr could be working now.

Log interleaving isn't because of 3 output functions.  If that was the case it would be interleaved on function call boundaries, but it's not.

You'll need https://gerrit-legato/#/c/19481/ and use 	apps/test/framework/rtos/multi-app/multi-app.sdef to see interleaving for yourself.

commits.commitMessage:
Remove mutex lock in eventlopp trigger function

The eventLoop trigger function calls pthread_cond_signal() to tell the
event loop a new event is ready to be processed. This must be done in
a critical section to prevent a race condition when accessing the
condition variable.
This patch removes the mutex lock from the trigger function which code
is already inside the critical section of the caller.

Resolves: LE-8335
Change-Id: I1631dfcbb77ca9d1a06e8f5cd3afd220869f39a8
commits.subject: Remove mutex lock in eventlopp trigger function

commits.commitMessage:
Improve memory usage on hl78.

Compile liblegato with --ffunction-sections --fdata-sections to put
each function and data item in its own section.  This allows selectively
GNU ld to only include functions which are actually used in the final
link.

Resolves: LE-7550
Change-Id: I15e9f4da591d0dc5287f0a3d18cd50adfc411005
commits.subject: Improve memory usage on hl78.

commits.commitMessage:
Add Altair MAP 1250 implementation for thread

Resolves: LE-7551
Change-Id: I51c9329ef7030c5d261e8494bf7617ea9597622c
commits.subject: Add Altair MAP 1250 implementation for thread

comments.message: See previous comment about nice levels, le_thread_SetPriority() etc.

Yes but there are some points which seem bad in the current implementation.
In le_thread.h there are definitions LE_THREAD_PRIORITY_RT_HIGHEST and LE_THREAD_PRIORITY_RT_LOWEST which are based on le_thread_Priority_t enum and set the values to 1 and 32.
The problem is that these limits are platform dependent.
In our case we're limited to 10 levels (defined in map/Core/include/config.h).

I think that le_thread.h should be modified.
LE_THREAD_PRIORITY_RT_HIGHEST and LE_THREAD_PRIORITY_RT_LOWEST should refer to OSes defines which could be take by legato.h?

In fact there are 2 POSIX functions to do that:
- sched_get_priority_min
- sched_get_priority_max
The POSIX compliance implies a minimum of 32 levels ...

Can we considerer this code as a POSIX compliant?
If yes, I think that we can assume that the pthread adaptation from Altair deals with the POSIX priorities and scheduler, no?

First: I think it's very dangerous to assume Altair code is POSIX compliant.  Their "POSIX" layer is very incomplete, and not actually POSIX compliant in many cases.

Second: Your call to le_thread_SetPriority() here is not correct.  First you are passing a nice level for the second parameter, when it takes a priority.  Second, all le_thread_SetPriority() does when the priority is LE_THREAD_PRIORITY_{LOW,MEDIUM,HIGH} is set threadPtr->priority, it doesn't actually change the priority of the OS thread.  But you are using threadPtr->priority to determine which priority to set!  The control flow is circular and does nothing for these priorities.

First: ok I agree. What do you think to make this file POSIX compliant (with #ifdef CONFIG_LINUX for linux specific parts) to be able to put it in legato/framework/liblegato and create a specific file in frameworkAdaptor to handle the problems between POSIX and Altair POSIX/OpenRTOS?
Does Altair support pthread_getspecific?  It's not documented in the RiceKrispies_SDK document I have.
it seems the prototype is in the header files ...
nm -a libpthread.a does not have a pthread_getspecific function.  So unless it's an inline function I think it's probably not present.
Maybe "Altair MAP 1250" if you must mention it.
You need an implementation of this as well.
Is there a reason to violate the coding rules? the correct name should be SetPriority
yes it is the POSIX prototype ...
This file contains the declarations of things that are implemented in thread_posix.c, so shouldn't this file be called thread_posix.h?
I've called it resource_fa.h by analogy with the POSIX includes where these definition come from <sys/resource.h>

This is not in agreement with the man page for setpriority().  The implementation should be changed to match the man page as closely as possible, and the differences between the man page and this implementation should be clearly documented in the function header.

This is because the most likely place that someone will go looking for documentation on POSIX functions is the man page.  The second most likely place they will look is the include file or the implementation.

Also, in general it's good practice to provide more detailed error feedback (e.g., a log message indicating the specific error), so that the developer doesn't have to use trial and error to troubleshoot errors.

On which point it is not compliant with the man page ?
http://pubs.opengroup.org/onlinepubs/9699919799/functions/setpriority.html

> This is because the most likely place that someone will go looking for documentation on POSIX functions is the man page.  The second most likely place they will look is the include file or the implementation.

Agree but I think that it is what I've done? The header is in resource_fa.h with the limitations.

Keep in mind that this is just a wrapper between common legato code and OpenRTOS.

Agree for the log message but here I think that these errors are very uncommon, no?

> On which point is is not compliant with the man page?

The man page (under "ERRORS") says:

 [EINVAL]
     The value of the which argument was not recognized,
     or the value of the who argument is not a valid process ID,
     process group ID, or user ID.

But you are returning the EINVAL error code when the prio argument is out of range too.

...But the main non-compliance is that the function doesn't actually do anything. :)
Hmm... Why are we even implementing setpriority()?

Pure POSIX implementation (which we're using for RTOS) uses it for HIGH, NORMAL and LOW priority threads.  But since pure POSIX doesn't allow setting per-thread nice value anyway, maybe the POSIX implementation should treat these all as "normal" and not call setpriority(), as we will effectively be doing on RTOS anyway.
ok so everybody is ok to remove this function and to modify thread.c to handle all the cases as NORMAL for the POSIX implementation?
Anything included by a file in include needs to be in include.
Not important to me, but maybe we don't need this check at all.  Since the priority is ignored, this stub function could just accept any argument.
Yes I've done this at beginning because I thought that there had more code but after analyze it seems that there is nothing to do. I've pushed it as it was. But I can remove it, if you prefer?

Doesn't matter to me either way.  The advantages of removing it I thought were:

1) If someone calls this with which != PRIO_PROCESS it would not fail unexpectedly.
2) If we ever turn on link-time optimization (LTO), if the function is completely empty the linker might be able to optimize it out.

But both of these are not issues at the moment, so I would think to push as is & change later if needed.

If this is even allowed (see my comment on Altair license) this should all go in the Altair MAP code, not framework adaptor.  At this point it's not a framework adaptor; it's a modification to Altair's pthread library.
I agree but as the situation is not clear about what we want tot do and how I've kept the code here.
Since we don't do anything with nice value we can get rid of this.  I think at least one of our static analysis tools would complain about statements with no effect.

For the moment none of the static analysis tools complained.
But ok to remove this code.

Here I would assert(state == PTHREAD_CANCEL_DISABLE), and always return *oldstate = PTHREAD_CANCEL_DISABLE.  Since we don't support thread cancellation, it's better to error on code which expects thread cancel to work as soon as possible.

If we assert we'll have a problem with our implementation of semaphore which is using this API.


Anyway this API only sets a state. This state is used in pthread_cancel(). As we've an assert in pthread_cancel there is no problem with the behavior of pthread_setcancelstate().

But ok to return always PTHREAD_CANCEL_DISABLE in oldstate if you prefer.

We will only have a problem if anything tries to enable cancellation.  In the more usual disable/restore case there will be no problem as "oldstate" will always return  disabled.

If semaphore is currently enabling it should be restoring oldstate instead, as it doesn't know if cancellation is already disabled.
I would not include this function at all, and fix up any code which calls it instead.  LE_FATAL() always means nothing should be calling it anyway, so it's better to catch that at compile time.
include this function avoids to do a modification in legato code or apps code ...
You're not going to be able to avoid modifying old code.  The old code isn't going to work if a function it relies on does LE_FATAL() every time it's called.

thread_cancel is called from le_thread_Cancel.
If we suppress this code we'll need to modify thread.c ...
I guess that the other calls are done through legato API not through pthread API.
On RTOS this space should be allocated statically in the structure, not dynamically allocated.  On this kind of device predictable memory usage is more important than minimal memory usage.
Ok but in this case perhaps we need to reduce PTHREAD_KEYS_MAP because if we allocate it statically it will use 4k by thread ...
We will always be creating TLS for every thread in Legato, so it needs to be some number we can support for every thread.

This should all go in the Altair pthread.c.  What we're doing here is really extending their code, so I think it's clearer to structure it that way.

Then we can give them our modified version and maybe they will incorporate into a future release.

At the same time we should to create a "Altair" branch with unmodified code for taking their source drops so we can merge in new code.
I think it's better to keep our code here for the moment. This will make the merge simpler as long as we're not sure that Altair is ok to incorporate our modifications.
What about putting in a pthread_extra.c alongside Altair pthread then?  Because there's so much here it's not a framework adaptor anymore -- it's half a POSIX thread implementation.
Yes it could be a good solution. I hope that we can add simply a file without the need to modify the build system.

comments.message: Perhaps it's better to put them in legato.h (frameworkAdaptor)?
Yes.  I've created LE-8062 to do this move, as it also affects liblegato and a few other places, so I don't want to combine with this already very large patch.
I think that semaphore.h can be included without the custom_os/ to be POSIX compliant.

To do this we need to add ${LEGATO_ROOT}/framework/include/$os_type to the include path, which we are not doing now.

I think it's better to individually call out things which we're pulling from the OS-specific directory.  Our implementation of semaphores isn't fully POSIX compliant anyway as far as I know (no shared semaphores).

Note I've moved semaphore.h from liblegato to include/custom_os as external headers (those in /include) should not depend on internal headers (those in /liblegato)

The problem is that some code (especially TU) will not compile if we need to do <custom_os/semaphore.h> instead of <semaphore.h> because they include directly semaphore.h
Even if our implementation is not fully POSIX I think it's better to keep the same includes.

I wonder then if we should create a separate library for our POSIX layer, separate from liblegato?

Although maybe if code doesn't compile because it's trying to include <semaphore.h>, that's a positive.  I think we should take the opportunity to switch it to le_semaphore API instead.

There's been a bit of debate in RMD if Legato should assume a POSIX API is present, and for other platforms (such as OpenRTOS) write a partial POSIX layer, or if we should write our own OS abstraction layer (maybe as part of liblegato) and write everything on top of that abstraction layer.  Any thoughts?

(TU -- Tests Unitaires?)

Yes TU is UT (Unitary Tests), sorry. :)

Yes, that can be the opportunity to clean the code. Especially as some file include semaphore.h without the need ...

For the separate lib, it could be a good idea but I'm not sure that it's in the scope of this project. It's a big work especially in term of validation, no?

I think it would be a lot of work to do a proper POSIX layer.  Personally I'd rather clean up code so everyone uses the le_semaphore API.

I think if we expect people outside liblegato implementation to use the semaphore.h POSIX API, the implementation needs to be 100% POSIX compliant or we will see bugs in the code using it.  And as you say making sure it's POSIX compliant seems like a lot of work.

No need to appologize -- I just wanted to make sure I understood the abbreviation correctly.

Hmmm, I do find it odd that we are leaking "custom_os" into the specific altair-1250-map include files. Seems backward.
Custom_os is only there because we don't want to call it altair.

commits.commitMessage:
Add Altair MAP 1250 implementation for mutex and semaphore

Resolves: LE-7561 LE-7558
Change-Id: I64a398f6a92c2fb2a964499aa984d9abb02b7b4c
commits.subject: Add Altair MAP 1250 implementation for mutex and semaphore

comments.message: Shouldn't it disable thread cancellation before locking instead?  Otherwise if thread is cancelled in the middle the semaphore could be left in an inconsistent state.

There is a race here.  If sem->value is changed before sem_wait() is called, sem_trywait could still block.  Instead you need to lock the mutex before testing sem->value, and not unlock until after semaphore wait code.
You're right. So the factorization in sem_Lock becomes less relevant because I think we need to set PTHREAD_CANCEL_DISABLE before to lock the mutex, no?

Yes, that way the mutex will always be unlocked when it is canceled.

One pattern I have seen in the Linux code is if a function does locking, factor it into 2 functions: one which has the main algorithm with no locking, one which just takes the lock and then calls the first function.  So you could maybe factor sem_Lock into two functions along those lines.
If we want to remain POSIX compatible the only errors allowed are EINVAL and EOVERFLOW. What do think to return EINVAL here ?
Need to unlock mutex before returning.
I think this should be LE_FATAL() instead.  The program can't reasonably continue after a failed unlock.
I think you should lock the mutex before reading the value.  Otherwise you need to ensure read, increment and decrement are all atomic.
Would be better to keep lock & unlock in same function.

I've a mixed feeling about this.
It'll break the factorization, all these functions are static to the file and function name is explicit. So for me it's under control.
